verse:
पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि स: |
जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते || 44||
transliteration: pūrvābhyāsena tenaiva hriyate hyavaśho ’pi saḥjijñāsur api yogasya śhabda-brahmātivartate
word meanings: pūrva—past; abhyāsena—discipline; tena—by that; eva—certainly; hriyate—is attracted; hi—surely; avaśhaḥ—helplessly; api—although; saḥ—that person; jijñāsuḥ—inquisitive; api—even; yogasya—about yog; śhabda-brahma—fruitive portion of the Vedas; ativartate—transcends
translation: By that very former practice he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmic word.
commentary: Once spiritual sentiments have sprouted, they cannot be wiped out. The soul with devotional sanskārs (tendencies and impressions) from the present and past lifetimes gets naturally inspired toward spirituality. Such an individual feels drawn toward God, and this pull is also referred to as “the call of God.” Based upon the past sanskārs the call of God sometimes becomes so strong that it is said, “The call of God is the strongest call in one’s life.” People who experience it reject the entire world and the advice of their friends and relatives to tread the path that draws their heart. That is how in history, great princes, noblemen, wealthy businesspersons, etc. renounced the comfort of their worldly position to become ascetics, yogis, sages, mystics, and swamis. And since their hunger was for God alone, they naturally rose above the ritualistic practices prescribed in the Vedas for material advancement.

newest_commentary: Once spiritual sentiments are awakened in the soul, they cannot be erased. Individuals with past and present devotional tendencies are naturally inclined towards spirituality and feel a strong pull towards God. Referred to as the 'call of God,' this inner yearning can be overwhelming. Those who experience it often forsake the world and disregard the advice of friends and family to follow their heart's calling. Throughout history, many prominent figures like princes, nobles, and wealthy individuals have abandoned their worldly comforts to become ascetics, yogis, sages, mystics, and swamis. Their sole pursuit was God, leading them to transcend the ritualistic practices of the Vedas and seek spiritual growth instead of material success.
